newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish shares rebound, seen locked in tight range.
newsitem.headline: Polish shares rebound, seen locked in tight range.

text.p: Polish shares rebounded after a three-day fall but analysts said the stronger selling after price-fixing signalled a fall on Friday and that the market was still in its month-long sideways trend.

"The market could slip a little tomorrow...but we can still say we're in a horizontal trend and that there's no reason for the trend to change," said Pawel Tarnowski, an analyst at Raiffeisen Capital & Investment.
Some analysts said a relatively busy public-offering schedule later this month gave reason to believe the market could fall slightly before year-end.
Others said there was a chance money could stay with listed shares as recent bourse debuts have proved modest.
"People may be leaving that (the primary) market because profits there after bourse debuts have been relatively stable," said Krzysztof Zawila, an analyst at Penetrator brokerage.
The main market's WIG index rose 0.8 percent to 13,634.6 and turnover was stable at 77.5 million zlotys on both markets.
Analysts said investors would be watching food prices for the last 10 days in November, due on Friday, to help determine November's inflation figure due later in the month.
Analysts said top gainer Optimus, up 7.4 percent in active trade, may have been helped by recent buy recommendations and the approaching holiday season, when computer sales should rise.
Continuous trade turnover was at 6.1 million zlotys with four stocks down and two up.
NFI units eased 0.4 percent to 139 zloltys in a 12.5-million-zloty turnover in the regular bourse session and fell 3.5 percent to 136 zlotys in 11.1-million-zloty continuous trade.
